headline: Sugar Cone Ice Cream Recipe
description: For die hard lovers of the ice cream cone, here's an ice cream that tastes just like one.
name: Sugar Cone Ice Cream Recipe
recipeIngredient: 3 cups half-and-half (or 1 1/2 cups each cream and whole milk)

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat to 350°F (175°C).

In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, whisk egg yolks together with sugar until very well combined, pale yellow in color, and slightly thick. Whisk in half-and-half until well combined, then bring saucepan over medium heat. Cook, stirring frequently, until a custard forms on the back of a spoon and a finger swiped across the back leaves a clean line, or until custard reaches 170°F (77°C).

In the meantime, place sugar cone crumbles in a single layer in a sheet pan and toast in oven until they darken in color and begin to smell toasted, 2 to 3 minutes, keeping an eye on them to ensure they don't burn. Carefully transfer toasted cone crumbles to a blender.

Strain cooked ice cream base into blender carafe, cover, and let sit for 15 minutes, then blend until cones are completely puréed into base, about 30 seconds. Add vodka and salt to taste. Strain into an airtight container and refrigerate, or into a bowl over an ice bath, and chill until base cools down to 40°F (4°C).
Churn base according to manufacturer's instructions. Serve right away as soft serve or transfer ice cream to airtight container and chill in freezer for at least 4 to 5 hours before serving.

review.reviewBody:
@Max

The Tosi recipes calls for toasting, so I'd do that. I'd probably also use her base. It has a lot more sugar, and includes a healthy amount of glucose syrup.
@arbeck Though if you steep and strain you may want a sweeter and fattier base. This one might turn a little icy.
@Max how different do you think it would be if you used Tosi's cereal milk recipe but substituted the cones for the cereal? I've had good luck with that recipe in the past.

@Toddlessness Because of all the puréed cone, this ice cream is very thick. So thick, in fact, that without some softener, it's too firm—not in an icy way, but more like super-dense frozen brownie. Vodka softens the ice cream and gives the ice cream a looser, more palatable body. As long as you use a not-terrible brand it shouldn't give an alcoholic bite. 

The ice cream is still very rich, though. Definitely feels like you're eating ice cream-softened cone.
